article_title: Harris Health considers job, service cuts to bridge budget gap
article_text: To continue reading this story, you will need to be a digital subscriber to HoustonChronicle.com.

article_metadata.description: An impending $71.8 million budget shortfall could force Harris County's primary public health agency to close school-based clinics, cap other services and eliminate jobs, agency leaders said Friday.  Agency officials attributed the budget gap to an expected increase in patient volume and a projected decline in certain categories of Medicaid funds.  A report this week by a state task force estimated that if Texas opted in to the expansion, it could provide health insurance coverage to an estimated 1 million additional residents and prevent billions of dollars in federal taxes paid by Texans from going to other states to fund their programs.  State Rep. Garnet Coleman, D-Houston, called Harris Health's impending budget shortfall one more casualty of Texas not participating in the Medicaid expansion.  "Greg Abbott believes that Texas should be able to address our unique health care situation without federal interference, putting patients and doctors in charge of health care decisions," said the spokeswoman, Amelia Chasse.  Harris Health's estimated $71.8 million shortfall for the fiscal year starting March 1 would occur if most spending remained at 2015 levels and most jobs and capital expenditures were capped, said George Masi, the agency's president and CEO.
article_metadata.author.name: By Kyrie O'Connor
